questions.text: A segment of the dorsal root ganglia was taken from a cadaver and examined under microscopy, and the neuron's cell bodies were identified. In their cytoplasm, dark blue bodies were identified with a special stain, as shown in the image below. Which of the following is true about these stained structures?

choices.text: They consist of the rough endoplasmic reticulum
They consist of the smooth endoplasmic reticulum
They are only found in the cell bodies of the neurons
They are found in the neuronal cell bodies, the dendrites, and the axons

questions.solution:
The dorsal root ganglia comprise a group of neuronal cell bodies outside the central nervous system. When examining these cell bodies under microscopy, few structures can be identified.  

Nissl bodies or Nissl granules are groups of structures in the cytoplasm of the neuronal cell bodies identified by their darker color. These Nissl bodies can be stained with a special stain called Nissl stain.  

Nissl bodies are comprised of rough endoplasmic reticulum and ribosomes. They are seen in the neuronal cell bodies and also can be seen in the dendrites. However, Nissl bodies are not found in the axons.


Option Analysis

✅ They consist of the rough endoplasmic reticulum  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ They consist of the smooth endoplasmic reticulum  :
Incorrect: The Nissl bodies are darker granules in the cytoplasm of the neuron cell bodies and the dendrites and consist of the rough endoplasmic reticulum and ribosomes.  
❌ They are only found in the cell bodies of the neurons  :
Incorrect: Nissl bodies are found in the cell bodies of neurons and the dendrites.  
❌ They are found in the neuronal cell bodies, the dendrites, and the axons  :
Incorrect: Nissl bodies are only found in the neuronal cell bodies and the dendrites; they are not seen in the axons.  
❌ They consist of the mitochondria  :
Incorrect: Nissl bodies consist of the rough endoplasmic reticulum and ribosomes. They do not contain mitochondria.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presents to the emergency department with worsening weakness and shortness of breath. The patient feels unsteady on his feet and has been tripping over himself while walking. Additionally, he has dyspnea at rest and feels like he “cannot take a deep breath.” The patient had a sore throat approximately 2-3 weeks ago but is otherwise healthy. He does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 10/min, blood pressure is 130/64 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 93% on room air. His negative inspiratory force is 27 cm H2O (normal >60 cm H2O). Which of the following additional clinical features is most likely to be observed on physical exam?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with lower extremity weakness and shortness of breath after a recent viral illness. His findings are most consistent with Guillain Barré syndrome, which is a cause of lower motor neuron disease. Of the clinical findings listed, fasciculations, or muscle twitches that result from incomplete firing of the damaged lower motor neuron, are most consistent with this disease.  

In general, upper motor neuron diseases refer to lesions of the neural pathway above the anterior horn of the spinal cord or motor nuclei of the cranial nerves. Classic examples include stroke, intracranial hemorrhage, and cerebral palsy. In contrast, lower motor neuron lesions affect nerve fibers traveling from the anterior horn of the spinal cord to associated muscle tissue. Examples include Guillain-Barré syndrome, myasthenia gravis, and cauda equina syndrome.    

Distinguishing between upper and lower motor neuron diseases can be elicited by a careful neurologic examination. Upper motor neuron lesions result in disinhibition of lower motor neurons, resulting in excitatory symptoms including increased muscle tone, spastic paralysis, hyperactive reflexes, and postive Babinski sign. In contrast, lower motor neuron lesions result in inhibition of muscle contraction and cause flaccid paralysis, muscle atrophy, decreased deep tendon reflexes, and fasciculations.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Fasciculations:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Spastic paresis:
Incorrect: Spastic paresis is a complex condtion characterized by paralysis and muscle spasms. It is associated with etiologies leading to upper motor neuron disease, such as strokes, intracranial bleeding, or cerebral palsy. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms are more concerning for Guillain-Barre syndrome, which is a lower motor neuron disease. 
❌  Increased muscle tone:
Incorrect: Increased muscle tone is associated with upper motor neuron disease. This phenomenon occurs since upper motor neuron damage leads to loss of inhibition of lower motor neurons, resulting in sustained muscle contraction. 
❌ Babinski reflex:
Incorrect: The Babinski reflex is a normal reflex in infants, characterized by upgoing toes when the sole of the foot is stimulated with a blunt instrument. In adults, this finding is pathologic and consistent with upper motor neuron disease. However, this patient’s history of muscle weakness and shortness of breath after a recent respiratory infection is more consistent with Guillain-Barre syndrome, which leads to lower motor neuron symptoms. 
❌ Clonus:
Incorrect: Clonus refers to a series of rhythmic repeating muscle contractions and relaxations in response to reflex stimulation. This finding is more commonly observed in patients with upper motor neuron lesions. In contrast, this patient most likely has Guillain-Barre syndrome, which causes lower motor neuron symptoms.

questions.text: Researchers are studying the neuronal action potential. The study finds that the first step involves opening ligand-gated ion channels, which allows calcium ions into the muscle cell, thus increasing membrane potential positivity. This step triggers the opening of voltage-gated ion channels and depolarization due to the influx of ion X. After a few milliseconds, another voltage-gated ion channel opens and allows molecule Y to efflux outside the cell, causing repolarization of the cell membrane. Which of the following is most likely ion X and Y?
questions.solution:
The neuronal action potential allows an electrochemical signal to be transmitted through the neuron. It usually starts when a neurotransmitter binds to dendrites and triggers the opening of ligand-gated ion channels. When open, these channels allow for the entrance of a positively charged ion into the cell, causing slight depolarization of the membrane and bringing it closer to the action potential threshold. When these interactions occur, they are referred to as  excitatory postsynaptic potentials (EPSP).  
 

Once the cell reaches a voltage-gated threshold, voltage-gated sodium channels open, allowing sodium ions to influx into cells and induce depolarization. The influx of sodium brings the membrane potential up to around 40 mV, and the action potential propagates through the axon.  


The voltage-gated sodium channels become inactivated once the membrane potential reaches around 40 mV. Although these channels remain open, no sodium enters the cell. At this point, voltage-gated potassium channels are available, causing an efflux of potassium outside the cell, bringing the membrane potential towards repolarization and membrane resting potential (~ -65mV).  The cell during this period is in the effective refractory period, meaning that no matter the strength of the signal, no additional action potentials can be initiated.  


After the cell membrane reaches the resting potential, potassium channels remain open, allowing membrane potential to become more negative, a setting called hyperpolarization. At this stage, sodium channels remain closed, and the neuron remains in the relative refractory period.  


The voltage of the neuronal action potential phases is summarized in the chart below:  


Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Sodium influx into the cell causes depolarization, while potassium efflux causes repolarization.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Chloride is not responsible for the repolarizing neuronal action potential. Potassium ions efflux through the voltage-gated ion channels causing repolarization.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Calcium and Chloride channels may play a role in stimulating or inhibiting action potential in neurons, but they are not responsible for the action potential itself.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Calcium ions are not responsible for depolarizing the membrane in neuronal action potential, which is completed by the influx of sodium ions through voltage-gated ion channels.

questions.text: Cerebral blood flow can remain fairly constant over a wide range of cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP). Which of the following changes will result in a reduced CPP?
questions.solution:
Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is the difference between mean arterial pressure (MAP) and intracranial pressure (ICP) (or central venous pressure [CVP]) if it is more significant than ICP. CPP is dependent on MAP. MAP is normally 80 to 100 mm Hg. A reduction in blood pressure or elevation of ICP can reduce CPP.

Moderate to severe increases in ICP (>30 mm Hg) can compromise CPP and CBF, even in the presence of a normal MAP. Sustained perfusion pressures less than 25 mm Hg may result in irreversible brain damage.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Increase in intracranial pressure (ICP):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increase in PaCO2:
Incorrect: CPP is directly proportional to PaCO2 until PaCO2> 90 mm Hg. An increase in PaCO2 will increase the CPP.  
❌ Decrease in PaO2:
Incorrect: Hypoxemia increases CPP only when PO2 < 50 mm Hg. It does not reduce the CPP.  
❌ Increase in systemic blood pressure:
Incorrect: An increase in blood pressure will increase the mean arterial pressure (MAP), which increases the gradient between MAP and ICP, leading to an increase in CPP.  
❌ Decrease in central venous pressure:
Incorrect: Central venous pressure [CVP] affects the CPP only when it is more significant than ICP. Moreover, a reduced CVP will increase the CPP.

questions.text: Therapeutic hyperventilation may treat acute cerebral edema unresponsive to other interventions. Which changes during hyperventilation enhance cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP)?
questions.solution:
Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is determined by the pressure of the blood reaching the brain (mean arterial pressure [MAP]) and the ICP acting against this blood pressure:

CPP = MAP — ICP

Therefore, if ICP rises at a constant MAP, cerebral perfusion pressure will fall, leading to decreased cerebral perfusion.

Increases in the respiratory minute volume mediated by increases in tidal volume and respiratory rate result in alveolar hyperventilation that decreases the PaCO2 causing cerebral vasoconstriction, reduced CBF, decreased cerebral blood volume, and decreased ICP. Therefore, therapeutic hyperventilation may be used to treat acute cerebral edema (e.g., 2° to stroke) unresponsive to other interventions.  

Option Analysis

❌ Increase in PO2:
Incorrect: During hyperventilation, which lowers arterial PCO2 and increases the blood pH, the average PO2 decreases in proportion to the decline in arterial PCO2.  
❌ Decrease in central venous pressure:
Incorrect: Central venous pressure [CVP] affects the CPP only when it is greater than ICP. Moreover, it is not affected by therapeutic hyperventilation.  
❌ Increase in intracranial pressure:
Incorrect: Increases in the respiratory minute volume mediated by increases in tidal volume and respiratory rate result in alveolar hyperventilation that decreases the PaCO2 causing cerebral vasoconstriction, reduced CBF, decreased cerebral blood volume, and decreased ICP.  
✅ Decrease in PCO2:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decrease in systemic blood pressure:
Incorrect: Hyperventilation causes vasoconstriction and an increase in systemic blood pressure.

questions.text: Polysomnographic profiles define two basic states of sleep: (1) rapid eye movement (REM) sleep and (2) non–rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep. Which of the following stages and waveforms corresponds to the stage of sleep during which bruxism occurs?

choices.text: Awake with eyes closed and beta waveform
Stage N2 with sleep spindles and K complexes

questions.solution:
Polysomnographic profiles define two basic states of sleep: (1) rapid eye movement (REM) sleep and (2) non–rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep. NREM sleep is further subdivided into three stages: N1, N2, and N3 characterized by increasing arousal threshold and slowing the cortical EEG. REM sleep is characterized by a low-amplitude, mixed-frequency EEG similar to that of NREM stage N1 sleep, and the EOG shows REMs, which tend to occur in flurries or bursts. EMG activity is absent in nearly all skeletal muscles except those involved in respiration, reflecting the brainstem-mediated muscle paralysis characteristic of REM sleep.

Stage 2 of non-REM sleep is marked by the appearance of sinusoidal waves called sleep spindles (7–15 Hz), and occasional high voltage biphasic waves called K complexes. Bruxism also occurs during this stage of sleep. A summary of sleep stages is described below.
   

Option Analysis

❌ Awake with eyes closed and beta waveform:
Incorrect: In adult humans who are awake but at rest and with eyes closed, the most prominent component of the EEG is a fairly regular pattern of waves at a frequency of 8–13 Hz and amplitude of 50–100 µV.  This pattern is the alpha rhythm.  
❌ Stage N1 with alpha waveform:
Incorrect: Stage 1 non-REM sleep is the transition from wakefulness to sleep, and EEG shows a low-voltage, mixed frequency pattern. A theta rhythm (4–7 Hz) can be seen at this stage of sleep.  
✅ Stage N2 with sleep spindles and K complexes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stage N3 with beta waveform:
Incorrect: Stage 3 of non-REM sleep is characterized by the appearance of a high-amplitude delta rhythm (0.5–4 Hz) on EEG, reflecting a further reduction in arousal, and a further reduction in muscle tone.  
❌ REM sleep with theta waveform:
Incorrect: During REM sleep, characteristic rapid, roving eye movements occur during this stage of sleep and are recorded as an electrooculogram (EOG). Except for eye movement, there is almost a complete loss of skeletal muscle tone in REM sleep. The threshold for arousal from sleep by sensory stimuli is elevated during this time. A beta rhythm (highest frequency, lowest amplitude) can be seen at this stage.

questions.text: The blood-brain barrier is absent in several specialized regions collectively called circumventricular organs. Which of the following structures is considered the vomiting center of the brain?
questions.solution:
The blood-brain barrier (BBB) is absent in several specialized regions of the brain collectively called circumventricular organs. These areas are: (1) the posterior pituitary (neurohypophysis) and the adjacent ventral part of the median eminence of the hypothalamus, (2) the area postrema, (3) the organum vasculosum of the lamina terminalis (OVLT, supraoptic crest), and (4) the subfornical organ (SFO).

The area postrema is concerned with cardiovascular control, where circulating angiotensin II produces a neurally mediated increase in blood pressure. The circumventricular organs have fenestrated capillaries and are said to be “outside the blood-brain barrier.” These organs function as chemoreceptor zones for many peptides and substances.  

Option Analysis

❌ Posterior pituitary:
Incorrect: Posterior pituitary is one of the circumventricular organs but is not the vomiting center.  
❌ Organum vasculosum lamina terminalis:
Incorrect: Organum vasculosum lamina terminalis (OVLT) is the site of the osmoreceptor controlling vasopressin secretion. Evidence suggests that circulating interleukin-1 (IL-1) produces fever by acting in the organum vasculosum lamina terminalis.  
✅ Area postrema:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Subfornical organ:
Incorrect: Angiotensin II acts on the subfornical organ (SFO) to increase water intake. It is not the vomiting center of the brain.  
❌ Median eminence of the hypothalamus:
Incorrect: Ventral part of the median eminence of the hypothalamus is one of the circumventricular organs, but it is not the brain's vomiting center.

questions.text: Autoregulation of cerebral blood flow refers to the ability of the brain to maintain a relatively constant blood flow despite changes in perfusion pressure. Which of the following is the primary regulator of cerebral perfusion?
questions.solution:
Autoregulation of cerebral blood flow (CBF) refers to the ability of the brain to maintain constant blood flow despite changes in perfusion pressure. The most important extrinsic influences on CBF are respiratory gas tensions—particularly PaCO2 levels. CBF is directly proportional to PaCO2 between 20 and 80 mm Hg. Blood flow changes approximately 1 to 2 mL/100 g/min per millimeter of mercury change in PaCO2.

Whereas hyperoxia may be associated with only minimal decreases (–10%) in CBF, severe hypoxemia (PaO2 <50 mm Hg) significantly increases CBF. This effect is almost immediate and is thought to be secondary to changes in the pH of CSF and cerebral tissue. Because ions do not readily cross the blood-brain barrier, but CO2 does, acute changes in PaCO2 but not HCO3– affect CBF. Only marked changes in PaO2 alter CBF.

Cerebral perfusion autoregulation also relies on a gradient between mean arterial pressure (MAP) and intracranial pressure (ICP). Decreasing blood pressure or ICP reduces cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP).
 

Option Analysis

❌ PaO2:
Incorrect:  Cerebral perfusion autoregulation is driven by PCO2. PO2 modulates perfusion in  severe hypoxia and hypoxemia increase cerebral perfusion pressure only if PO2< 50 mm Hg.  
✅ PaCO2:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blood-brain barrier:
Incorrect: The blood-brain barrier (BBB) prevents circulating substances (e.g., bacteria, drugs, medications) from reaching the central nervous system. It does not play any role in the autoregulation of cerebral perfusion as oxygen and carbon dioxide freely enter the brain.  
❌ Chemoreceptor trigger zone:
Incorrect: The chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ), located within area postrema, is the site of action of multiple antiemetic drugs. It does not play any role in the autoregulation of cerebral perfusion.  
❌ Intracranial pressure:
Incorrect: Cerebral perfusion autoregulation relies on a pressure gradient between mean arterial pressure (MAP) and intracranial pressure (ICP), but not the intracranial pressure alone.

questions.text: The blood-brain barrier (BBB) strives to maintain the constancy of the environment of the neurons in the CNS. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement about the BBB?

choices.text: Lipid-soluble substances cannot cross the BBB freely
Circumventricular organs have an intact BBB
It is formed by fenestrated capillary endothelial cells
Glucose crosses the BBB by carrier-mediated transport mechanisms
The area postrema has an intact BBB

questions.solution:
The blood-brain barrier (BBB) strives to maintain the constancy of the environment of the central nervous system. Functions of the blood-brain barrier include protection of the brain from toxins, autoimmune regulation, and prevention of neurotransmitter escape into general circulation.

Four structures form the BBB:
 
  •  Tight junctions between non-fenestrated capillary endothelial cells 
  •  Basement membrane 
  •  Astrocyte foot processes 
  •  Pericytes 
The BBB allows for the passage of lipid-soluble substances but restricts the movement of those that are ionized or have large molecular weights. Thus, the movement of a given substance across the blood-brain barrier is governed simultaneously by its size, charge, lipid solubility, and degree of protein binding in the blood. Therefore, carbon dioxide, oxygen, and lipid-soluble molecules (such as most anesthetics) freely enter the brain, whereas most ions, proteins, and large substances (such as mannitol) penetrate poorly.
   

Option Analysis

❌ Lipid-soluble substances cannot cross the BBB freely:
Incorrect: Nonpolar/lipid-soluble substances cross the BBB rapidly via diffusion.  
❌ Circumventricular organs have an intact BBB:
Incorrect: Circumventricular organs have fenestrated capillaries and are said to be “outside the blood-brain barrier.”  
❌ It is formed by fenestrated capillary endothelial cells:
Incorrect: The BBB is formed by tight junctions between non-fenestrated capillary endothelial cells.  
✅ Glucose crosses the BBB by carrier-mediated transport mechanisms:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The area postrema has an intact BBB:
Incorrect: The area postrema is a circumventricular organ with fenestrated capillaries and no blood-brain barrier.

questions.text: Sleep cycle is regulated by circadian rhythm via a complex interplay of hormones and deep brain structures. Which of the following structures in the brain drives circadian rhythm?
questions.solution:
Sleep is a naturally recurring state characterized by altered consciousness, inhibited sensory activity, inhibition of voluntary muscles, and reduced environmental interaction. Specifically, sleep is distinguished from wakefulness by a decreased ability to react to stimuli but is more easily reversed than the state of hibernation or being comatose.

The circadian rhythm regulates the sleep cycle, which is driven by the hypothalamus's suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN). The circadian rhythm controls the nocturnal release of ACTH, prolactin, melatonin, and norepinephrine, which in concert determine the duration and quality of sleep.  Ultimately, circadian rhythm is entrained to light/dark cycles as stimulated by neurons in the retina. Light signals are relayed via the retinohypothalamic (RHT) fibers to the SCN, which then stimulates the release of norepinephrine and stimulates the pineal gland to secrete melatonin and induce sleep.

Option Analysis

❌ Preoptic nucleus:
Incorrect: The preoptic nucleus of the hypothalamus is involved in thermoregulation and sexual behaviors. It releases GnRH and has no significant effect on circadian rhythm.  
❌ Ventral posterolateral nucleus:
Incorrect: The ventral posterolateral nucleus of the thalamus relays senses of vibration, pain, pressure, proprioception (conscious), light touch, and temperature to the primary somatosensory cortex.  
❌ Lateral nucleus:
Incorrect: The lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus is referred to as “the hunger center”. It is stimulated by ghrelin and inhibited by leptin.  
✅ Suprachiasmatic nucleus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Supraoptic nucleus:
Incorrect: The supraoptic nucleus of the hypothalamus synthesizes antidiuretic hormone, which does not affect circadian rhythm.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of trauma to his right thumb. The patient was playing with his brother when he accidentally slammed the door on the patient’s thumb. Physical exam shows the patient has an avulsion injury of the right thumbnail. In order to repair the injury without significant pain, the emergency physician performs a digital block via injection of xylocaine at the base of the right thumb. Which of the following types of nerve fibers anesthetized during this procedure are most susceptible to blockade by the aforementioned medication?
questions.solution:
This patient undergoes a peripheral nerve block with xylocaine for repair of a nail avulsion injury to the right thumb. When considering the type of nerve fibers best anesthetized by local anesthetics, the size factor predominates over myelination such that small myelinated fibers are most sensitive to these medications.      

Local anesthetics inlude medications such as procaine, tetracaine, benzocaine, chloroprocaine, lidocaine, mepivacaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine and all carry a similar mechanism of action. These medications all work by binding to specific receptors on the inner portion of the sodium channel, preventing the flow of sodium ions, and subsequently blocking the initiation and propagation of action potentials. Local anesthetics are most effective at blocking fast firing nerves--e.g. smaller fibers. Myelinated fibers are blocked more easily than unmyelinated fibers. In the setting of two fibers with equal degrees of myelination, the smaller fiber will be more sensitive to local anesthesia.      

In accordance with this pattern, the degree of sensation loss after administration of local anesthetics includes pain first, followed by temperature, touch, and finally pressure. In addition, pain firing fibers tend to be located more superficially in tissues, such that fibers located in the periphery of a thick nerve bundle are blocked faster than those in the core because they are exposed to higher concentrations of anesthetic.  

Option Analysis

✅  Diameter   Degree of Myelination  2 µm  ++++ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Diameter  Degree of Myelination  15 µm ++++ :
Incorrect: These measurements are indicative of Type A alpha nerve fibers, which conduct proprioception and motor movements. This type of neuronal fiber has an overall low sensitivity to local anesthetic blockade.
❌  Diameter   Degree of Myelination  8 µm  ++++ :
Incorrect:  These measurements are indicative of Type A beta nerve fibers, which conduct the sensation of touch and pressure. This type of neuronal fiber has an overall moderate sensitivity to local anesthetic blockade.
❌  Diameter   Degree of Myelination  6 µm +++:
Incorrect: These measurements are indicative of Type A gamma nerve fibers, which innervate muscle spindles. This type of neuronal fiber has an overall moderate sensitivity to local anesthetic blockade.
❌  Diameter   Degree of Myelination  .5 µm-:
Incorrect: These measurements are indicative of Type C dorsal root ganglion fibers, which conduct pain. This type of pain fiber is small and unmyelinated, and has a high sensitivity to blockade via administration of local anesthetics. However, given the anatomic location of the aforementioned procedure, these fibers would not be blocked.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents for evaluation of a boil on his upper back. The patient initially had a small comeodone that he scratched, and it subsequently progressed to become larger and more painful over the past week. The patient has a history of multiple sclerosis and takes baclofen daily for treatment of muscle spasms. The patient has an allergy to tetracaine, and broke out in hives when having a laceration repaired several years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a 2 cm x 2 cm fluctuant abscess over the thoracic spine. The patient is subsequently injected with bupivacaine subcutaneously, directly over the area of highest fluctuance in preparation for incision and drainage. A stab incision is made over the anesthetized area; however, the patient reports significant pain despite administration of bupivacaine. Which of the following best describes the etiology of the phenomenon described above?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of an upper back abscess and has a local amide anesthetic injected prior to incision and drainage. Unfortunately, this provider did not adequately assess for post-injection analgesia – which was poorly controlled in this patient, likely due to injection into acidic tissue.    

Local anesthetics include medications such as procaine, tetracaine, benzocaine, chloroprocaine, lidocaine, mepivacaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine and all carry a similar mechanism of action. These medications all work by binding to specific receptors on the inner portion of the sodium channel, physically preventing the flow of sodium ions, and subsequently blocking the initiation and propagation of action potentials.   

These medications are inherently weak organic bases that are composed of charged and uncharged forms when in solution–only the uncharged forms are able to exert effects on sodium channels. In acidic solutions (such as in infected tissue), lower pH reduces the proportion of anesthetic in the uncharged form according to Henderson-Hasselbalch equation, resulting in decreased ability for the anesthetic to penetrate the neuronal membrane. Ultimately, this results in more anesthetic required to anesthetize this type of tissue. 

Option Analysis

✅ Increased acidity of injected tissue :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Localized allergic reaction :
Incorrect: While this patient has an allergy to ester anesthetics, he is provided with an amide anesthetic, bupivacaine. This patient's clinical presentation is not consistent with an allergy reaction.  
❌ Medication interaction :
Incorrect: Baclofen does not interact with administration of local anesthetics.   
❌ Poor injection technique :
Incorrect: The provider described in this vignette used adequate technique for local anesthesia--the issue was likely injecting an insufficient amount of anesthetic.   
❌ Degradation of injected medication :
Incorrect: Local anesthetics are not degraded when injected into acidic tissue--they can degrade over time if left out, especially in sunlight environments.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a finger laceration. The patient was cutting tomatoes in the kitchen when the knife slipped and he sustained a laceration to his left middle finger.  The patient is subsequently injected with a medication on the palmar aspect of his left hand just proximal to the left middle finger. After several minutes the patient reports absence of pain, but can still sense pressure. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the medication utilized in this procedure?

choices.text: Non-specific blockade of voltage gated Na+ channels
Inhibition of release of acetylcholine from presynaptic motor neurons

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of a finger laceration and subsequently has a digital block performed with administration of a local anesthetic. The mechanism of action of these medications involves non-specific blockade of voltage gated Na+ channels to block neuronal transmission of pain signals.  

Local anesthetics include medications such as procaine, tetracaine, benzocaine, chloroprocaine, lidocaine, mepivacaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine and all carry a similar mechanism of action. These medications work by binding to specific receptors on the inner portion of the sodium channel, physically preventing the flow of sodium ions, and subsequently blocking the initiation and propagation of action potentials. These medications are most effective in rapidly firing, small diameter, highly myelinated neurons, which comprise the majority of pain associated fibers. Thus local anesthetics are exceptionally effective agents for nerve blocks, minor skin procedures, or prior to placement of indwelling catheters.  

Option Analysis

✅ Non-specific blockade of voltage gated Na+ channels:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ NMDA receptor antagonism:
Incorrect: NMDA receptor antagonism describes the mechanism of action of ketamine, a dissociative analgesic. This medication is commonly used for procedural sedation, not local anesthesia.   
❌ Acetylcholine receptor agonist :
Incorrect: Depolarizing nerve agents such as succinylcholine function by selectively binding acetylcholine, and inducing prolonged depolarization, preventing muscle contraction. These medications are frequently utilized as paralytic agents during rapid sequence intubation, not for local analgesia.   
❌ Acetylcholine receptor antagonism:
Incorrect: Non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking medications such as rocuronium work by competitively binding the acetylcholine receptor, preventing muscle contraction. Like depolarizing neuromuscular blockers, these medications are not used for local analgesia.   
❌ Inhibition of release of acetylcholine from presynaptic motor neurons:
Incorrect: This stem describes the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin, the agent found in the medication botox, used to achieve long-term muscle paralysis. This medication is not used for local analgesia.

questions.text: A medication for the treatment of chronic pain is under study in rat models. In addition to analgesia, administration of this medication results in decreased gastrointestinal motility, bowel movements, and respiratory depression. Stimulation of which of the following receptors is most likely responsible for these additional clinical effects?
questions.solution:
There are three primary receptors involved in opiate pharmacology: μ, δ, and κ. Most opiates operate primarily on the μ-opioid receptor, which in addition to analgesia, contributes to the side effects of constipation, decreased gastrointestinal motility, and respiratory depression.     

While there is some overlap and distinction of effects at these receptors, they are all G-protein coupled receptors. The binding of associated endogenous ligands modulates synaptic transmission via closure of presynaptic Ca2+ channels and opening of postsynaptic K+ channels. These changes inhibit the release of ACh, norepinephrine, 5-HT, glutamate, and substance P, resulting in decreased synaptic signal transmission.  



Option Analysis

✅ μ-opioid receptor :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ κ-opioid receptor :
Incorrect: The κ-opioid receptor contributes to analgesia at the spinal level and may elicit sedation, dysphoria, and hallucinations. Agonism at this receptor does not induce constipation.   
❌ δ-opioid receptor :
Incorrect: The δ-opioid receptor is primarily responsible for analgesia and has proconvulsant properties. Agonism at this receptor does not induce constipation.   
❌ GABAA receptor :
Incorrect: Medications including benzodiazepines, barbiturates, and sedative-hypnotics act on the GABAA receptor. They do not typically cause constipation as a side effect.   
❌ NMDA receptor :
Incorrect: Ketamine is a dissociate agent that acts on the NMDA receptor. It does not typically cause constipation as a side effect.
